Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A merger contract contains clauses that could expose the client to immediate financial liability if not examined promptly.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the text from Alex: “Let’s pick a night for our date! We finally have time.” My heart fluttered—he’d been so patient with my late nights and missed dinners. This week, for once, our schedules aligned. I could almost taste the relief of a quiet evening together, just us, no distractions. But as I reached for my calendar, my work email pinged. The subject line made my stomach drop: “URGENT: Merger Contract Review Needed.” The document was attached, thick with legalese and red flags. If I didn’t comb through it now, my client could face serious losses. I knew what was expected of me—meticulous attention, immediate action. But Alex’s hopeful message tugged at me. I wanted to be present, to show him he mattered. My mind raced, torn between the promise of laughter over dinner and the weight of responsibility pressing from my inbox. I sat frozen, phone in one hand, contract in the other, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds.
